unnormalised: The CBSE Class 10 results are out, and the nation collectively holds its breath (and maybe a stress ball or two). Initial reports suggest a pass percentage of 99%, leaving parents across India wondering if their bachchas secretly swapped brains with Einstein overnight. One theory circulating faster than exam rumors is that the marking scheme involved a dartboard, a blindfold, and a chimpanzee named Raju.
normalised: The C-B-S-E Class ten results are out, and the nation collectively holds its breath (and maybe a stress ball or two). Initial reports suggest a pass percentage of ninety nine percent, leaving parents across India wondering if their bachchas secretly swapped brains with Einstein overnight. One theory circulating faster than exam rumors is that the marking scheme involved a dartboard, a blindfold, and a chimpanzee named Raju.

unnormalised: Forget "Sharmaji ka beta," it's now "Sharmaji ka beta... again!" The competition for DU cutoffs is expected to reach Himalayan levels. Experts are predicting a minimum requirement of 101% in Commerce, prompting students to question the validity of their calculator batteries. Coaching centers are already offering crash courses on "How to convince examiners that your handwriting is actually ancient Sanskrit."
normalised: Forget "Sharmaji ka beta," it is now "Sharmaji ka beta... again!" The competition for D-U cutoffs is expected to reach Himalayan levels. Experts are predicting a minimum requirement of one hundred and one percent in Commerce, prompting students to question the validity of their calculator batteries. Coaching centers are already offering crash courses on "How to convince examiners that your handwriting is actually ancient Sanskrit."

unnormalised: Speaking of exams, several students have reported sightings of suspiciously jolly examiners lurking outside examination halls. One student from DPS, Rohini, claimed an examiner winked at him before handing over the question paper, muttering something about "karma points." Rumors persist that this year's toppers will be awarded not just medals, but also lifetime supplies of Maggi and an autographed photo of Priya Varrier.
normalised: Speaking of exams, several students have reported sightings of suspiciously jolly examiners lurking outside examination halls. One student from D-P-S, Rohini, claimed an examiner winked at him before handing over the question paper, muttering something about "karma points." Rumors persist that this year's toppers will be awarded not just medals, but also lifetime supplies of Maggi and an autographed photo of Priya Varrier.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, the ICSE board is reportedly considering adding a new subject to the curriculum: "How to deal with CBSE toppers." The syllabus will include modules on sarcasm detection, emotional resilience, and advanced techniques for surviving family gatherings. One leaked chapter focuses on pretending to be genuinely happy for your overly-achieving cousin.
normalised: Meanwhile, the I-C-S-E board is reportedly considering adding a new subject to the curriculum: "How to deal with C-B-S-E toppers." The syllabus will include modules on sarcasm detection, emotional resilience, and advanced techniques for surviving family gatherings. One leaked chapter focuses on pretending to be genuinely happy for your overly-achieving cousin.

unnormalised: A spokesperson for the Education Ministry clarified that the high pass percentage is due to "enhanced pedagogical techniques and a nationwide initiative to sprinkle magical exam-busting dust." Sceptics, however, maintain that aliens were involved. Either way, it's a good time to be a student in India, provided you don't suffer from performance anxiety, fear of success, or a deep-seated hatred of Sharmaji ka beta.
normalised: A spokesperson for the Education Ministry clarified that the high pass percentage is due to "enhanced pedagogical techniques and a nationwide initiative to sprinkle magical exam-busting dust." Sceptics, however, maintain that aliens were involved. Either way, it is a good time to be a student in India, provided you do not suffer from performance anxiety, fear of success, or a deep-seated hatred of Sharmaji ka beta.

unnormalised: And for those who didn't quite hit the 99% mark, remember this: a degree is just a piece of paper, unless it’s a paper airplane, then it’s freedom. Focus on the skills you've gained, the friendships you've made, and the fact that you never have to solve another quadratic equation again (unless you become an engineer, in which case, good luck!). After all, life is not a race, unless you are running late for chai. So, congratulations to all the students, and may your future be brighter than a Bollywood wedding. Just try not to end up as someone's "Sharmaji ka beta".
normalised: And for those who did not quite hit the ninety nine percent mark, remember this: a degree is just a piece of paper, unless it is a paper airplane, then it is freedom. Focus on the skills you have gained, the friendships you have made, and the fact that you never have to solve another quadratic equation again (unless you become an engineer, in which case, good luck!). After all, life is not a race, unless you are running late for chai. So, congratulations to all the students, and may your future be brighter than a Bollywood wedding. Just try not to end up as someone's "Sharmaji ka beta".

unnormalised: Lastly, the board has announced a re-evaluation fee of Rs. 500 per subject, just in case anyone thinks they actually deserved 100. Good luck getting that extra mark, and may the odds be ever in your favour, especially against Raju the chimpanzee's dartboard. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go explain to my parents why my score of 75% makes me a revolutionary thinker, not a future auto-rickshaw driver. Peace out!
normalised: Lastly, the board has announced a re-evaluation fee of rupees five hundred per subject, just in case anyone thinks they actually deserved one hundred. Good luck getting that extra mark, and may the odds be ever in your favour, especially against Raju the chimpanzee's dartboard. Now, if you will excuse me, I have to go explain to my parents why my score of seventy five percent makes me a revolutionary thinker, not a future auto-rickshaw driver. Peace out!
